content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about <math alttext="C 2 H 4 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>. (a) <math alttext="C 2 H 4 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> (molar mass <math alttext="44.06 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mn>44.06</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi> <mo>/</mo> <mi>mol</mi> </math>) is a gas at room temperature and can be harmful at concentrations above <math alttext="8.17 times 10 to the negative 6 power molarity" overflow="scroll"> <mn>8.17</mn> <mo>×</mo> <msup> <mn>10</mn> <mrow> <mo>-</mo> <mn>6</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> </math>. What is the maximum mass of this compound that can safely be present in a room with a volume of <math alttext="3.00 times 10 to the 5 power liters" overflow="scroll"> <mn>3.00</mn> <mo>×</mo> <msup> <mn>10</mn> <mn>5</mn> </msup> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi> </math>? Two structures, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>, with the molecular formula <math alttext="C 2 H 4 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> are shown in the table.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about <math alttext="C 2 H 4 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>. (a) <math alttext="C 2 H 4 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> (molar mass <math alttext="44.06 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mn>44.06</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi> <mo>/</mo> <mi>mol</mi> </math>) is a gas at room temperature and can be harmful at concentrations above <math alttext="8.17 times 10 to the negative 6 power molarity" overflow="scroll"> <mn>8.17</mn> <mo>×</mo> <msup> <mn>10</mn> <mrow> <mo>-</mo> <mn>6</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> </math>. What is the maximum mass of this compound that can safely be present in a room with a volume of <math alttext="3.00 times 10 to the 5 power liters" overflow="scroll"> <mn>3.00</mn> <mo>×</mo> <msup> <mn>10</mn> <mn>5</mn> </msup> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi> </math>? Two structures, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>, with the molecular formula <math alttext="C 2 H 4 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> are shown in the table.

(b) Based on <math alttext="V S E P R" overflow="scroll"><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></math> theory, predict the <math alttext="H single bond C single bond H" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> <mo>-</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi> <mo>-</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> </math> bond angle in structure <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>.

(c) A student incorrectly claims that <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> are resonance structures of each other. Explain why the student’s claim is incorrect.

<math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> are both gases at room temperature and <math alttext="1 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"> <mn>1</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext>atm</mtext> </math>, and they react according to the following equation. <math alttext="X is in equilibrium with Z" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi> <mo> </mo> <mo>⇄</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi> </math> (d) Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></math>, in terms of the partial pressures of <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>.

(e) For the reaction represented above, the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></math>, is <math alttext="3.3 times 10 to the negative 8 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></msup></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Which would have a greater partial pressure at equilibrium: the reactant, <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, or the product, <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>? Circle one of the options and justify your choice.<math alttext="Option 1: The partial pressure of reactant X is greater. Option 2: The partial pressure of product Z is greater." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>Option</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mn>1</mn><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>Option</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>:</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>The</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>partial</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>pressure</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>of</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>r</mtext><mi>eactant</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>is</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>greater</mi><mo>.</mo></mtd><mtd><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>The</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>partial</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>pressure</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>of</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>p</mtext><mi>roduct</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>is</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>greater</mi><mo>.</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

(f) An empty vessel is filled with compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and sealed shut. The initial pressure of compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is <math alttext="0.55 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.55</mn><mo> </mo><mi>atm</mi></math>. Calculate the partial pressure of compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> in the vessel after equilibrium is established at constant temperature.

(g) The sample is compressed to half of the original volume, without any change in temperature. Does the value of <math alttext="K sub p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></math> increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your choice.

(h) In the reverse reaction, the conversion of compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> to compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is catalyzed in the presence of trace amounts of water. The catalyzed reaction is proposed to occur via the following two-step mechanism.<math alttext="Step 1: Z plus H 2 O reacts to produce Y, which is slow. Step 2: Y reacts to produce X plus H 2 O, which is fast." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>Step</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mn>1</mn><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mtd><mtd><mo>→</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></mtd><mtd><mfenced><mi>slow</mi></mfenced></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>Step</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></mtd><mtd><mo>→</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mtd><mtd><mfenced><mi>fast</mi></mfenced></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>(i) Identify the intermediate in the mechanism, if any.
(ii) A reaction profile of the uncatalyzed reaction is shown above. On the same axes, sketch a reaction profile consistent with the proposed mechanism for the catalyzed reaction.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
